byline.contributor: Michael D. Shear reported from Washington, and Nicole Perlroth from San Francisco.
byline.original: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR and NICOLE PERLROTH

abstract: Cybersecurity officials warn that computer networks belonging to a number of federal agencies remain vulnerable to cyberattacks, despite push by Obama administration to shore up nation's computer defenses following June systems breach at Office of Personnel Management; many federal agencies are still run on out-of-date equipment with poor security and some point to lack of urgency on part of government officials.
lead_paragraph: Officials and experts acknowledge that the computer networks of many federal agencies remain highly vulnerable to sophisticated cybercriminals, who are often sponsored by other countries.

headline.main: U.S. vs. Hackers: Still Lopsided Despite Years of Warnings and a Recent Push
headline.print_headline: U.S. vs. Hackers: Still Lopsided Despite Years of Warnings and a Recent Push

snippet: Officials and experts acknowledge that the computer networks of many federal agencies remain highly vulnerable to sophisticated cybercriminals, who are often sponsored by other countries.
